physDesc.p: The letter consists of five sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of each. At the top of each new sheet is a heading, with “R.A.” and a page number on the left and the date on the right. There are a few places where words have been scratched out or inserted, and there appears to be a faint, illegible watermark on the paper.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Thank you very much for your copy of the Renaissance poems, and please thank Hilda for her “Choruses from Iphegeneia.” I am delighted to have them, only I wish you had written in them, and not merely signed them. You must write in your book for me, will you?

I went through your proof on Sunday, and it is just as well I did, for there were several quite bad mistakes: one whole line was left out, one word was wrong, and one title was left out in the table of contents, besides various minor mistakes. I have sent them to Brown with a note, requesting that I may be allowed to see the proofs again after they are corrected, for I wish to do everything in my power to get your book quite right. It looked very well, I thought, in print, especially the one (whose names I have forgotten) with a little golden cock pecking at the blue wheat-fields of the sky. It is rather funny, in the Christmas number of the “Century” I spoke of a golden cock with his mouth open. I did not put it as prettily as you did. I said a little piece of the sky was wedged in his beak; but it shows that we both have been impressed by that gesture of weathercocks. My poem was written last Spring, long before I saw yours, and you have never seen mine, which makes the unconscious plagiarism amusing.

I have sent three of Hilda’s poems to “The Century:” “Pear-tree,” “The Contest,” and “Sea Gods.” I Had a note from Benét yesterday, saying that they should have his immediate attention. I hope they will take them, for “The Century” pays very well, but I am a little bit doubtful, they are so queer about the things they take and the things they don’t.

I had a letter from Margaret Anderson the other day, and she asked me to send her some poems of yours and Hilda’s, saying that you had authorized her to ask for them. I sent her your “Bloomsbury Square” and “Epigram,” and Hilda’s “Late Spring” and “Night.” I hope that this will meet with your approval.

Ferris Greenslet is making me very miserable by requesting the manuscript of the Anthology as soon as possible. He now says he wants it by the end of January. I told him I did not see how we could have it as soon as that, and we were still to hear from England about some of the things. I have received two poems from Lawrence this morning. I suppose you have seen them; but as you did not mention them, and as he says he is leaving Hampstead at once, I am enclosing copies. Of course, they are neither of them Imagist poems, that is the truth of the matter. He writes a very nice letter, and says he knows he is not an Imagist, and he will not mind in the least if we turn them down, but I do not think, with this row about Lawrence in England, that we can turn them down. They have none of the objections that his work sometimes has, as you know, and I think “Erinees” is really a very fine thing, although I think the end is a little weak. The other is just a bit too vague and cosmic for me, as I suppose it is for you too. Of course, there are only two, but he says they are the only ones he has which we can possibly want. If you know any differently, I wish you would make him add others; but these are fairly long, and will certainly take up as much space as he is entitled to. Send me a line, telling me that the rest of you approve, and I will put them in.

I am enclosing some poems of Mrs. Untermeyer’s, which I am very anxious for you to see. She is very new at the business, as I wrote to you in my last letter, but I think these poems show good possibilities, and there is a feeling, a personality, in her verses which is perhaps more visible to a woman than to a man but which I personally think unusual and very beautiful; and I think Hilda will agree with me. Most of these poems have been accepted by magazines over here. On account of her husband, who is very well known, she has the inside track with a number of papers. But the last one, “Clothes,” has not been printed, and I have asked for it for “The Egoist.” Of course, I told her that I had no right to accept poems for “The Egoist,” but I feel sure that you will want to print it. I also asked her whether she would be willing to go into the Anthology, if we did put in any extra people another year; in other words, whether she was willing to subscribe herself an Imagist, and she is very willing, I think delighted. As I told you before, it is not only a good thing to have her on our side on account of her own work, in which I personally recognize a high quality, but because her husband is one of the most enthusiastic and hard-working critics we have, and he himself is improving daily.

I cannot remember whether I sent you Braithwaite’s Anthology or not, so I am sending you another copy in case I did not. I think you will think Untermeyer’s “Laughters” a fine thing. He writes for the “Chicago Evening Post.” He has a regular position there, as poetry critic; and to have his wife so obviously one with us at heart is certainly affecting his opinion of us in every way. I would not, of course, suggest your printing of one of her poems merely to get her husband’s good will; but both Fletcher and I think this poem, “Clothes,” excellent. But you understand that, if you do not like it, you are under no obligation to accept it.

It is awfully nice of you to want me to send you an article and some of my poems for your February number. I have not been able to have the photograph taken yet, and I am dreadfully afraid I cannot have it taken in time for that number. The pressure of work here is something terrific. I am doing all I can, but I have not been able to do that, so I am afraid you will have to go to press without my picture. Perhaps it is just as well, for I cannot think that my picture will be any gain to me.
I was immensely interested in the letters from the man in the German war prison in your last number. It makes me feel more than ever that “The Egoist” is having an effect.

I will send over some poems for your February number. “The Dinner Party” is, of course, one poem; and if you accept that, you will not need the shorter ones. But I am sending four short ones, in case you do not like “The Dinner Party,” and you can print the little ones as a group. IF you want to take “The Dinner Party” for this February and put the others in later, you are welcome to do so. If you do not want them, either all or sundry, send me back whatever you discard.

Fletcher has written a preface for the Anthology. I am afraid it is too long and too erudite. He is going to bring it out on Sunday, and we will work over it together, and get it off to you next week. You are then to make any changes or alterations you want, and send it back again. The time is getting awfully short, so do hurry, as Greenslet says the latest he can possibly have it is the first of February.

You say nothing about my poem, “Off the Turnpike,” which I sent to you sometime ago. Do you approve, or don’t you? The poem is under consideration at “The Century,” and if you like it, and if they accept it, I must make arrangements with them to publish it before the Anthology comes out. It occurs to me with a feeling of horror that you may be going to print “Off the Turnpike” in your February number. It would have been perfectly all right for you to do so, only I never thought of it, like a fool, and went and sent it to “The Century.” I do not believe they will accept it, but Benét asked me to send it. He is the first reader of “The Century,” but has not the final say, and the man who has, knows nothing about poetry. I know Benét is trying to force it on them, but I do not think he can. If you have taken it for “The Egoist,” and it is too late to substitute one of these others, please cable me; and then if you will tell me how much I owe you for the cable, I will gladly pay it, as “The Century” makes you sign a paper stating that the things you sent them have never been published before; and I shall get into no end of a mess, if they take it for “The Century” and it appears in “The Egoist.” I am awfully sorry to put you to this trouble, but I had not sent it to “The Century” when I sent it to you, and it was long before your suggestion that I submit something to “The Egoist” came, and so I never regarded it as going into “The Egoist” at all. I am awfully sorry.

Ferris Greenslet was very anxious to have us change the title of this year’s Anthology; but I told him that it was impossible, and that I did not think it advisable, and so we are calling it “Some Imagist Poets 1916,” with the “1916” very large and underlined. I trust that will do the trick.

Flint wrote me a perfectly beautiful review of my “French Poets,” so beautiful that it almost reduced me to tears. I have not heard from you or Hilda. I hope that does not mean that you do not like the book. It is doing very well here, and has nearly sold out its whole edition already, 750 copies gone out I heard by last accounts, and Mr. Marsh says we shall have to reprint before long. Two professors of the English Departments of Harvard and Yale have come out strongly in favour. Professor William Lyon Phelps, who is supposed to be one of the best things we have over here in literature, has written to the Macmillans to say that he considers it the most valuable work on French literature he has seen for a long time. Personally, I care very little for professorial opinion as much, but these things help with the public. I have very little hope for the sale in England. It is not a good time, and I do not think Americans are in very good favour over there just now. But still I hope. Do all you can to push it, won’t you?

postscript.label: P.S.
postscript.p: Fletcher has just telephoned to tell me that a letter from you, which I forwarded him to-day, contains the painful news that you have voted against both “Clipper Ships” and “Off the Turnpike.” I was afraid you might not like “Off the Turnpike” because, not knowing the Yankees and their customs, you cannot realize how true to their speech it is. I suggested it for the Anthology as a foil for the rest of the things in the book, for I have a theory that the more variety one can have, the better it is, and another one of this same New England series, which was published in “The New Republic,” made such an excellent impression here that I thought it would be good for the sale of the book to have this one in. But I daresay you are right in thinking it does not go, and I am quite willing to substitute something else, but what, it is a little difficult to decide.

I am sending you a choice. “Stravinsky” is the most remarkable poem of the lot, but I do not approve of it for the Anthology. In the first place, one should have heard the music to understand it. In the second place, its peculiar diction is sure to be taken as a huge joke by people who do not know Stravinsky and have not a chance, by a number of my poems together, to see what I am driving at. Therefore I do not approve of it for the Anthology, unless still a third poem is added to go with it.
I assume that you accept “The Spring Day” as one of my contributions, since you have not said anything about that to Fletcher.

Now “Lead Soldiers,” which I am also enclosing, is I think one of the best things I have done. You may not agree, on account of the little childish rhyme which keeps coming into it; but that is an effect I wanted to give, a sort of nursey rhyme, and to me it adds to the rest of the poem; but I do not think this poem so good here, as in that case my contributions will both be in “polyphonic prose,” and that I was trying to avoid. Too much of one metre.

“In a Time of Dearth” is very good, but too short to make the second contribution all by itself. In that case I should advise including with it the “Impressionist Picture of a Garden” or possibly “The Dinner Party,” if you like it enough. And then there is always “Patterns,” which you can have if you want to. And here is one called “The Paper Windmill,” which could be used with “The Spring Day” and one of the other vers libre things, but not as the second contribution by itself, it too being “polyphonic prose.
Now please send me your answer by return mail, and send back the poems at the same time. Ferris Greenslet is in such a hurry that we cannot delay three days.

Of these poems I am sorry that I can only submit those I mentioned in the letter and which I marked “unpublished” on the manuscript, for you to print in the February “Egoist.” “Lead Soldiers” has already appeared in “Poetry,” and “The Paper Windmill” in “The Century.” “In a Time of Dearth” has been accepted by “The Century,” “Stravinsky” is under consideration by “The Masses,” and “The Impressionist Picture of a Garden” is the same with the “Smart Set.”

I do think you are thoroughly mistaken in regard to Fletcher’s “Clipper Ships.” It is to my mind one of the best things he has done. It was published in “The New Republic” and had a good success. I do think that we should be careful and not let our theories of poetry interfere with our taking in really excellent poems. Fletcher’s “polyphonic prose” with bits of old sea “chanties” coming in, gives an extraordinarily vivid picture of the period; and even if you are not particularly interested in the period or particularly interested in the form, it seems to me the value of this Anthology is in allowing us all to develop on our own lines and letting the public see how each one has developed from year to year and how he differs from the others. If you cut out a poem of so great an originality as Fletcher’s, you will have, to my mind, set a dagger at the heart of the Anthology. Fletcher has a great and remarkable originality, and originality is the important thing in poetry.

Do not let your translations usurp too large a place in your work. Translations, no matter how good, are of minor importance compared to original work. Nobody knows that better than I, for have I not spent my entire Summer in making translations? For minor men, like Edward Fitzgerald, translating is important, but for poets of ambition and vigour, translating is only of value for two reasons: for boiling the pot, or for doing a little something when you have nothing else to do. Diving into other men’s minds is a delight and a temptation, but it must be kept in its proper place like any other vice. Vice for an original worker, that is.

Fletcher is not a bit sore about “Clipper Ships,” but I am rather, because I have the fate of the book extremely at heart, and I know it would be a good thing for the book to have “Clipper Ships” in it. Please believe my acumen when I tell you that, if we publish the present Anthology and do not have it more interesting, and arresting, and unusual, than the first, more full of different kinds of things, we shall come a cropper, for the first interest in our work will have subsided, and mere repetition of the same kind of thing will interest nobody. Our first Anthology was better than Ezra’s Anthology because it was not so monotonous. I think you must remember, in judging poems for this Anthology, that monotony is the great thing to be avoided. My only objection to including my own “Patterns” from our Anthology was that I thought the public had a right to demand something new, and “Patterns” Has already been published in Braithwaite’s Anthology and copied in many papers over the country. But if you want it, all right.

Of course, you shall have “Whitechapel” if your heart is set on it. Neither Fletcher nor I intended to take any arbitrary stand, we merely pointed out that we did not think it up to your standard. In judging poems to admit or exclude, we follow an entirely different line from the one that you follow. You take an abstract standard and insist that all poems shall conform to that. We have no hard and fast standard, we take your work on its own merits, and see whether it comes to measure favourably in effect with other work you have done. It would not make any difference if we were together and could pick them out, but with the mails taking so long to go and come, this choosing is a little bit difficult.

Now please write me back exactly what you want me to do about my own things. Fletcher and I will look over his things on Sunday and send you some more to choose from. Only whatever you say this time must be definite, as we have no time for the mail to come across again. Personally, I believe from the point of view of the public you are wrong not to let me have my “Off the Turnpike.” I am sure it would help sell the book. But, of course, if you feel strongly about it, that is all right, I don’t mind a bit.

On reading this over, I think I sound huffed. I am not, the least little bit in the world. I can perfectly understand that you don’t like dialect poems. Lots of people don’t. I would have written it in ordinary spelling, the same way Synge wrote Irish, but Yankee dialect is more a question of pronunciation and elision than of twisted syntax, and the effect would have been lost.

div.note: Aldington has sent Lowell a copy of a volume of the Poets' Translation Series, a series of twelve pamphlets of Greek, Latin, and Italian translations by Aldington and H.D. published by the Egoist Press.
